end.title: Razorback
end.creator_credit: Russell Mulcahy, Hal McElroy, UAA Films and Western
end.brief_description: Story of a female animal rights campaigner who vanishes in the outback. Her husband sets out to find her, coming up against a monstrous wild boar that’s terrorising the countryside. Stars Gregory Harrison and Arkie Whiteley with Bill Kerr, Chris Haywood and Judy Morris.

links.description: TERROR NULLIUS sampled heavily from the Australian New Wave and, in particular, Ozploitation films like Razorback. Ozploitation films were characterised by exploiting colloquial Australian culture.

links.description: Before he made Razorback, director Russell Mulcahy directed the first film clip to appear on MTV - ‘Video Killed the Radio Star’ by The Buggles. Lighting, special effects and editing techniques he learned on music videos informed the style of Razorback.

start.title: Mad Max 2
start.creator_credit: Byron Kennedy

video_links.name: Mad Max 2: The Road Warrior - Trailer

start.brief_description: Max Rockatansky returns as the heroic loner who drives the dusty roads of a postapocalyptic Australian Outback in an unending search for gasoline. Arrayed against him and the other scraggly defendants of a fuel-depot encampment are the bizarre warriors commanded by the charismatic Lord Humungus, a violent leader whose scruples are as barren as the surrounding landscape.

end.title: Alcheringa
end.brief_description: An Australian Broadcasting Commission television program of twelve 15 minute episodes initially broadcast weekly, that re-created, an imagined world of everyday Indigenous practices before the coming of the Europeans.

constellations_other.name: Setting the record straight
constellations_other.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

links.description: Bill Onus was a Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur who campaigned for Aboriginal rights and was active in the film and TV industry. Episode four of Alcheringa featured Onus making and demonstrating throwing boomerangs.

results.name: Taking it slow
results.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

key_work.title: Phantom Ride
key_work.credit_line:
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection

Daniel Crooks is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery, Australia and Future Perfect, Singapore
key_work.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, colour and audio
key_work.brief_description: Daniel Crooks’ Phantom Ride alludes to cinema history to create a seamless journey through a composite reality. By manipulating digital footage as though it were a physical material, Crooks has constructed a collaged landscape, taking us through multiple worlds and shifting our perception of space and time.

links.description: A Slow Year explores ideas of time – primarily through watching the seasons go by – Christian Marclay’s The Clock connects with time from a granular rather than seasonal perspective, engaging audiences minute by minute through a hundred years of screen history.

constellations_other.name: Taking it slow
constellations_other.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

links.description: Harking back to early cinema, when filmmakers hitched cameras to trains so audiences could experience exotic travel, Daniel Crooks’ artwork stitches together slow-moving landscapes and was filmed on disused railway tracks. It’s similar to the slow TV phenomenon exemplified by Bergensbanen.

links.description: While Bergensbanen is an antidote to fast-paced TV, A Slow Year is a reaction to the fast pace of contemporary videogames. Deliberately meditative, the game slows itself to a kind of digital poem.

end.title: Play School
end.brief_description: Play School is an Australian Gold Logie award-winning educational television show for children. It is the longest-running children’s show in Australia, and the second longest-running children’s show in the world.

constellations_other.name: Learning through play
constellations_other.description: Alexander Stitt and Bruce Weatherhead’s Zoetrope to Cinemascope educated children about the moving image through posters, cut-outs, puzzles and games, but moving image works have also been used to educate and entertain kids about all aspects of life.

constellations_other.name: Taking it slow
constellations_other.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

links.description: ABC’s Play School has always featured a clock, with the original rocket and flower clocks assuming iconic status and their removal represented the end of an era. Subsequent clocks have now become symbolic of transience.

results.name: Now watch this
results.description: In a video-saturated world, how do you keep focus? Do you keep a close eye on one thing, or step back and watch the parade of images go by, to see the whole thing?

key_work.title: CATARACT (concrete)
key_work.credit_line:
Daniel von Sturmer. Aotearoa New Zealand

Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video. Indefinite loop

Commissioned by ACMI
key_work.material_description: Multi-channel installation, aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video
key_work.brief_description: Everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality.

results.name: Big screen dreams

end.creator_credit: Hugh O'Connor
end.brief_description: A multi-image large-format film retelling of the Greek myth of Theseus and symbolizing the life of a modern man; each one in a personal labyrinth that must find their own path to triumph.

constellations_other.name: Big screen dreams
constellations_other.description: With groundbreaking technology and a unique cinema experience, today IMAX theatres are not only loved by audiences but championed by pioneering filmmakers like Christopher Nolan and James Cameron. Yet the route to get there was an unconventional one.

links.description: IMAX goes back to 1967 when a group of Canadian experimental filmmakers debuted a retelling of the Theseus myth, In The Labyrinth, which was groundbreaking for using 35 mm and 70 mm film projected simultaneously on to multiple screens: a precursors to IMAX technology.

end.brief_description: Ally Hayden shares her father’s interest in dinosaurs and archaeology. When he brings a mysterious fossil home, she’s convinced it’s a T-rex egg and isn’t wrong. When it breaks open she’s has visions of the Cretaceous period.

links.description: In The Labyrinth inspired filmmaker Norman Jewison to recreate similar techniques in The Thomas Crown Affair a year later. However, to expand their appeal, over the next 30 years IMAX became known for their documentaries like T-Rex: Back To The Cretaceous.

links.description: In the wake of the box-office breaking Titanic, Cameron teamed up with Bill Paxton for Ghosts of the Abyss which saw them explore the sunken wreck for the first time. The documentary was shown in IMAX 3D, as was Cameron’s biggest hit: Avatar.

end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2008

Featuring Heath Ledger’s legendary, Oscar-winning performance as the Joker, action-packed set pieces and philosophical musings not seen in superhero movies, The Dark Knight is one of the best.

links.description: Avatar, which was converted to IMAX 3D in post-production, is credited with solidifying IMAX’s status in a competitive theatrical market according. It hit cinemas a year after The Dark Knight, which was the first narrative feature partially shot in the format.

constellations_other.name: Pink subversions
constellations_other.description: Pink dominates Angela Tiatia's The Dark Current. The artist describes this particular colour as “artificial”, “unapologetic” and “pulsating with feminine energy”. In Tiatia's Sāmoan heritage “there is a brashness in the use of colour. I really wanted to embody that.”

constellations_other.name: Gender avengers
constellations_other.description: Thelma and Louise and Promising Young Woman both celebrate women taking revenge on men who sexually assault them, although victory is temporary as the characters perish because of their choices.

links.description: ‘Hello’ made Adele the first artist in history to shoot a music video for IMAX. Another groundbreaking female is Cathy Yan whose movie Birds of Prey was released in IMAX and made her the first Asian American woman to direct a superhero blockbuster.

constellations_other.description: Shadow play uses light and projection to tell stories – fundamentals that would evolve into cinematography. In the Wayang tradition, gunungan open and close performances and indicate scene changes and the puppets pass across the projection screen in a similar way to a wipe transition.

start.title: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert
start.creator_credit: Stephan Elliott, Al Clark, Michael Hamlyn, Latent Image and Specific Films
start.brief_description: When drag queen Anthony (Hugo Weaving) takes his act on the road with fellow cross-dresser Adam (Guy Pearce) and transsexual Bernadette (Terence Stamp). In their colorful bus, Priscilla, the three performers travel across the Australian desert performing for enthusiastic crowds and homophobic locals.

constellations_primary.name: Joy of drag
constellations_primary.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

constellations_other.name: Gender transcending larrikins
constellations_other.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

constellations_other.name: Hiding in plain sight
constellations_other.description: This print of upside-down heads is an early optical illusion featuring hidden characters. Movie studios have continued the tradition of playing with perspective in the bold designs, vivid colours and hidden meanings of film posters.

constellations_other.name: Dance sequins
constellations_other.description: Looking at dance, ballroom, the Glitter Trilogy and the Red Curtain Trilogy.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

recommendations.quote: The film's three leads have all swapped fabulous frocks for villainous outfits in superhero films. Terrance Stamp was Zod in Superman 2, Hugo Weaving was Red Skull in Captain America: The First Avenger and Guy Pearce was Aldrich Killian in Iron Man 3.

results.name: Perception, time and flickering images
results.description: Using a peep hole and a loop of rotating still images, mutoscopes control the point of view of the audience while also creating the illusion of depth. Filmmakers have since put optical tricks to work creating surreal scenes.

key_work.title: British Mutoscope featuring Charlie Chaplin reel
key_work.brief_description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope.

results.name: Thomas Edison

key_work.brief_description: After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Thomas Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats.

links.description: Directed by Thomas Edison, Bicycle Trick Riding No.2 (1899) lasts for just under a minute and features cycling stuntman Neidert performing tricks. It’s one of the earliest examples of the moving image. Edison would later go on to be played by Benedict Cumberbatch in The Current War.

start.title: True Blood
start.creator_credit: Alexander Woo, Brian Buckner, Nancy Oliver, Raelle Tucker, W. Mark McNair, HBO, Your Face Goes Here Entertainment and Chris Offutt
start.brief_description: True Blood is an American television drama series created and produced by Alan Ball. It is based on The Southern Vampire Mysteries series of novels by Charlaine Harris, detailing the co-existence of vampires and humans in Bon Temps, a fictional, small town in northwestern Louisiana. The series centers on the adventures of Sookie Stackhouse, a telepathic waitress with an otherworldly quality.

end.brief_description: A quartet of girls from a prep high school are recruited by a secret paramilitary academy to conduct cloak-and-dagger missions. Short film later expanded into a feature film with the same name.

links.description: True Blood was considered the start of ‘peak TV’ thanks to its ability to examine issues of race and sexuality through a genre lens. Directing and writing several episodes was groundbreaking filmmaker Angela Robinson, who got her start with the action-packed comedic short D.E.B.S.

end.title: But I'm a Cheerleader
end.creator_credit: Andrea Sperling, Leanna Creel, Lionsgate and The Kushner-Locke Company
end.brief_description: Megan is an all-American girl. A cheerleader. She has a boyfriend. But Megan doesn’t like kissing her boyfriend very much. And she’s pretty touchy with her cheerleader friends. Her conservative parents worry that she must be a lesbian and send her off to “sexual redirection” school, where she must, with other lesbians and gays learn how to be straight.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

links.description: One of the few openly gay and black women directors in Hollywood, Robinson broke through with the short D.E.B.S, which was adapted into a feature of the same name. Following schoolgirls groomed to be spies, But I’m A Cheerleader filmmaker Jamie Babbit also contributed to the script.

end.title: Strays
end.creator_credit: George Zakk, Zeljka Pavlinovic and Vin Diesel
end.brief_description: Rick (Diesel) is frustrated by the repetitious grind of one-night stands and aimless hustling. Whilst looking for more to his life he meets Heather (Lanza), a neighbour. Rick takes the opportunity to escape his boring life style with her, but soon finds that his volatile behaviour threatens to finish their relationship before it even really begins.

links.description: The Current War is a dramatised version of the race between inventors to deliver the electric power delivery system, featuring Edison, George Westinghouse, Nikola Tesla, and other historic figures. It was directed by Alfonso Gomez-Rejon, who also did The Town That Dreaded Sundown.

start.title: Thomas Alva Edison
start.brief_description: After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Thomas Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats.

links.description: The Town That Dreaded Sundown was a remake of the 1976 slasher of the same name, based on the true story of the Texarkana Moonlight Murders. Unlike the original, Gomez-Rejon’s film was staged like a play with long, continuous shots and seasoned theatre actors like Denis O’Hare from True Blood.
